title: Is it good to download free PDF versions of books? - Quora

response.answer_text: Some authors and some publishers will give away pdfs in order to create buzz, or as a teaser for other products. If you’re getting the books that way, then it’s fine. Some libraries will lend ebooks (although pdf formats are rare for ebooks — the format just doesn’t work well for ebooks), and those are legally purchased, and only one copy exists at a time within the lending software, so that’s legal, too. BUT if you’re talking about “shared” ebooks, then that’s stealing. There is only one way for most authors and publishers to support their effort in creating the book. That involves the control over the right to make copies. Piracy removes that control, and that’s what you’re really stealing — their ability to make a living from the work you obviously want (or want enough to bother finding, stealing, and reading it). There are some folks out there who have believe that paying for books is somehow unethical. Their logic has always seemed to me to be based upon egregiously false assumptions. If you think that writing for pay (or publishing that writing) is somehow wrong, the solution is to boycott those books, not to steal them. It’s the same way with all products that you feel are ethically challenged. You don’t buy them, but you also don’t steal them.
